Two careless agents encrypted their secrets with different RSA keys, unknowingly sharing a prime. Can you exploit this oversight to recover the flag? Ciphertext: 2046729067945265747830966380251016831038131816939050636597846306407437782172798215861348941327208643454859585267900214956870031920180416407477407427919268

The flag format is flag{...}
n=9035079376218917583608748976266973961284837573746250179095222086452510817388513672245321317119826622317675226455553788661988320786637794446290832451020091, n2=7491766193100560797550238953568185254304278118787839167120311348128647116132172172771072834910454047193274724929976266341616165075951466781739169253413007, e=4015087394799759078635936888224665429632042985181943420907676107344221662411753639747533225506345882613227886100435156880509461060726778901393700720733639

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{2b68hdwy}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 2046729067945265747830966380251016831038131816939050636597846306407437782172798215861348941327208643454859585267900214956870031920180416407477407427919268
vulnerability: shared prime
hint: When two RSA moduli share a common prime, computing GCD(n, n2) can reveal the shared prime factor.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=9035079376218917583608748976266973961284837573746250179095222086452510817388513672245321317119826622317675226455553788661988320786637794446290832451020091, n2=7491766193100560797550238953568185254304278118787839167120311348128647116132172172771072834910454047193274724929976266341616165075951466781739169253413007, e=4015087394799759078635936888224665429632042985181943420907676107344221662411753639747533225506345882613227886100435156880509461060726778901393700720733639
